Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Educating for the grand challenges at the intersection of biocomplexity and high-performance computing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the University of Missouri (MU), located in Columbia, MO, will support the training of 12 students for 9 weeks during the summers of 2014-2016. This award is supported by both the Directorates for Biological Sciences (Division of Biological Infrastructure) and Mathematical and Physical Sciences (Division of Mathematical Sciences). Pairs of student researchers, one from the computational sciences and the other from the life sciences, will work collaboratively at the interface of high performance computing and big data biology. Students will select from a diverse group of research projects, with a choice of mentors from five departments in the computational and life sciences. Example projects include developing parallel computing approaches to allow the identification of gene duplications that occurred with important evolutionary transitions such as the origins of mammalian placentation and using parallel computers and GPUs to infer the plant tree of life with data from high-throughput sequencing. In addition, participants will join other campus summer research programs -- attending professional development sessions, training in the responsible conduct of research, and participating in weekly sessions on parallel computing and biology. Participants will be recruited from a variety of institutions, with preference given to students from minority-serving institutions and undergraduate-only colleges. The PIs and research mentors will select the participants (half from the computational and half from the life sciences) and help them choose a computational or biological partner. Participants' progress will be assessed with pre- and post-tests covering the program's technical material. The program will be evaluated using NSF's common assessment tool.

Computation, and especially parallel computation, will be vital to science and engineering in the future, as increasing data volumes from instruments such as next-generation DNA sequencers generate enormous amount of data. The training and research experience offered at this REU site will give the participants unique opportunities to be trained in this important area.

Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http://muii.missouri.edu/reu_bigdata, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Gavin Conant; conantg@missouri.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Chi-Ren Shyu; shyuc@missouri.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over 3 years, a total of 37 undergraduate students were brought to the University of Missouri (MU) campus in Columbia, MO to participate in a number of research projects at the interface of biology and computational science. Ten faculty members from five different departments at MU served as scientific mentors for the program.  The student researchers worked in teams on projects as diverse as whether the microbes living in a sheep's digestive system help determine how well that sheep can grow, how nematode worms parasitize crop plants, how to use graphics processing cards, invented for gamers, to analyze huge quantities of DNA sequence data, how to use inbred lines of fruit flies to understand human diseases, and using dozens of full mammalian genomes to understand the genetic changes that underlay the appearance of the placenta in evolution.

The participants received hands-on instruction in a number of aspects of high-performance computational biology from the project PIs and other MU faculty. Topics covered in the weekly workshops included genetic simulations, uses of social networking ideas in biology, parallel programming in OpenMP and MPI, GPU programming and the use of cloud computing resources (NSF’s CyVerse program). The CyVerse accounts the students created are available from their home institutions, allowing them to continue to explore the uses of computation in biology even after leaving MU. The participants also learned presentation skills with poster presentations of their work at the end of each summer and, in some cases, at research conferences.  Eleven of the participants are listed as co-authors on published or submitted peer-reviewed research articles: the project contributed to 6 such publications. As an example, 4 REU participants appear as co-authors in the PI’s recent paper in the journal Microbiome.  In that paper, we describe how using advanced computational techniques allows us to link our understanding of how microbes benefit grazing animals to decades of ecology research on the optimal structuring of ecosystems.

Many of the participants are continuing their education with a focus on computational biology: several have applied or been admitted to Ph. D. programs, while others are applying to other research experience programs with computational components.
